An excellent tour through the philosophy of mind. But be warned: this is no ordinary popular science book. Penrose dives deep into many different areas: algorithms, mathematics, philosophy, cosmology, classical and quantum physics, cognitive science and even some biology on the inner workings of the brain. The reader is guided through these areas in search of an answer to the question: "Can a computer have a mind?", or conversely, "Can our minds be simulated by a computer?"Penrose argues against the Strong AI school of thought, which asserts that the human mind, and our consciousness, is a (very complex) algorithm that could in theory be simulated by a computer. In the end, I cannot say that this book convinced me of the truth of his standpoint, but it certainly does raise some doubts as to the truth of the Strong AI hypothesis. The Emperor's New Mind not only offers a look into the human mind, but also a look into the fascinating achievements it has made in the fields of science, mathematics and philosophy throughout the ages. I hope to read many more books like this one, but I doubt there will be many to find. Truly an exceptional work of popular science.

I enjoyed reading this - Penrose's hypotheses of quantum mechanics and Godel's Incompleteness Theorem playing a part in "consciousness" is an interesting one, and he does a good job arguing it. As a determinist and someone who believes brains are Turing complete, I am firmly in the camp of those who would debunk his work - but it can't be denied Penrose is an very intelligent physicist and argues logical concepts well. I think the primary issue is, he is not a neuroscientist, and outside inherent fallacies that his arguments may or may not have, there are simple physical problems with Orch-OR that have already been brought up, such as Tegmark's paper. Penrose is firmly in the camp of those that see "consciousness" as something incredibly meta that needs to be explained by the "magic" that is non-deterministic quantum mechanics. However, as neuroscience learns more and more, this is less and less likely. Not an easy read by any means, but if you're interested in ideas of consciousness and quantum mechanics, definitely a good read.

Penrose spends almost the entirety of the book building the groundwork for the reader to absorb the meat of the book's final chapter. It is tempting to skip around such as I did in chapter 4 (while I thought to myself "what on earth could this possibly have to do with the thesis") but even that chapter's take on tiling and fractals turned out to be building an important concept central to one of final chapter's conjectures. As for the final chapter itself, it is gripping and ambitious, with most of the rest of the book a review of other's work, it is here that the author bridges key concepts and moves into new territory. I found a lot of similarities between the structure of this book and another from the author - the road to reality - a road I struggled with at times and unfortunately put down midway through, now I feel I have to pick up again if for no other reason than to see if the emporer's final chapter can be topped. My thanks to Scott Aaronson who recommended both books in an essay available on arxiv titled "the ghost in the quantum Turing machine".

Despite the premise of the book, most of it does not really deal with the subject of intelligence directly, or even indirectly in many cases. This book was a good overview of some of the most important results in math, computer science, and physics (mostly physics) throughout history. In my opinion, it was very technical, and I have a degree in electrical engineering, so I think most readers would find the book fairly un-readable. A degree in physics is probably necessary to truly understand the entire thing. His hypotheses about consciousness in the last few chapters are very interesting. Basically, he seems to believe that human consciousness and intelligence cannot result from any type of algorithm, but rather there must be some deeper more complex phenomena going on, which may have to do with results in physics that have not yet been determined, like the unification of general relativity and quantum mechanics (correct quantum gravity as he calls it).

"The Emperor's New Mind" by Rodger Penrose is an attempt to survey the question of mind which takes two forms: the possibility of creating an artificial intelligence and what is mind in it's deepest nature. To achieve this goal he gives a very broad background and context which encompasses the whole reality as understood by modern physics. However, this physics is the standard textbook physics that one would find in university undergraduate courses. From this context consciousness (mind) doesnât follow. The book is only an "attempt" to look into the "possibility". The reader doesn't get the answer to the question what is mind. It is only the first step, and this is the main drawback of the book. Of course, now this book may be seen as outdated (first published back in 1989). More than 20 years after the first appearance of "The Emperor's New Mind" the standard for tackling the problem of natural or artificial mind is much higher.

This is a majestic work of an extraordinary intellect. Roger Penrose has my highest esteem for writing such a lucid and deep essay on the mathematical nature of reality, consciousness, and quantum mechanics. I went into this skeptical about the claims regarding quantum entanglement I'd read about second-hand that Penrose makes in here, but they're actually quite modest and admittedly speculative. Penrose strikes me first and foremost as an empiricist and second as an extraordinarily capacious mind, one that can synthesize cognitive neuroscience (ca. 1990), quantum mechanics, and mathematics. The cognitive neuroscience stuff I tended to skip over since I don't need to read it (being a former prof of the subject myself) and so I cannot speak to its quality. But everything else was sublime.

This was a very difficult book and I will admit I could not even follow the equations let alone solve them. But he nevertheless is able to make the case that the human mind is able to understand things no computer that operates according to any known principle will ever be able to do. He sites GÃ¶del's completeness theorem as demonstrating that humans can stand outside logical systems. He also accepts that mathematics partakes of an independent reality from the human mind, also known as Platonism. Bob Godwin describes it thus: "Platonism...claims that mathematics is descriptive of abstract entities, of numbers and sets, that exist separately from our attempt to understand them through our mathematical systems."

I flipped through this book last year and thought I'd say something about it. This book has a lot of gibber. The book's themes are superficially reminescent of Deepak Chopra with trying to connect quantum mechanics with consciousness, although Roger Penrose is much much smarter than Deepak Chopra and at least he accepts that he may be wrong. I wouldn't quite call it woo-woo like Chopra-talk but it is close. His assertation in the preface that microtubules inside our cells are the most likely place for consciousness (with no evidence) basically makes him lose all credibility in my mind.I will quote Michael Shermer, which I think sums up Roger Penrose."Smart people believe weird things because they are skilled atdefending beliefs they arrived at for non-smart reasons"

I was not at all convinced of the author's point or reasoning, but I appreciated some of the early/middle chapters that gave very clear and lucid explanations of current scientific understanding across many fields. What I didn't like was that the author essentially listed a number of current problems in scientific understanding and said, "Here these are, we don't currently understand them... therefore they must all be related!" I also in particular disagree with the idea that pain or pleasure and/or other feelings are not algorithmic processes. I think we have explained those impulses as being directly related to electrical/chemical signaling processes in the brain, which operate in an algorithmic fashion.

Penrose's basic premise is that consciousness arises from quantum mechanical interactions. There is no evidence for this, simply the assertion that since consciousness must arise from somewhere, and it's not obvious how it arises from neurological function, then it must come from something more fundamental -- quantum physics. The problem with this thesis is twofold: 1) just because we don't understand how consciousness arises from neurological processes doesn't mean that it can't and 2) even if it comes from something other than neurology, why should that something be quantum mechanics?
